awd_titl_txt: Catalyst Award: Nuclear Science at Virginia State University, Building Connections to FRIB Science
awd_abstract_narration:
Catalyst Projects provide support for Historically Black Colleges and Universities (HBCU) to work towards establishing research capacity of faculty to strengthen science, technology, engineering and mathematics undergraduate education and research. It is expected that the award will further the faculty member's research capability, improve research and teaching at the institution and involve undergraduate students in research experiences. The project at Virginia State University seeks to establish a nuclear science research group that will investigate neutron-unbound states of oxygen isotopes at the Facility for Rare Isotope Beams (FRIB) at Michigan State University.

This proposed work focuses on two areas: (1) analysis of data from past measurements performed with the MoNA (the Modular Neutron Array) Collaboration at National Superconducting Cyclotron Laboratory (NSCL) and (2) the development of a new segmented target to probe the structure of neutron rich nuclei. The former (1) will examine past measurements of various decay channels in order to extract information about the 27O level structure. It will involve computer programming to analyze and visualize the data as well as perform simulations using the GEANT4 toolkit to interpret the results. This data set was recorded during the first experiment to utilize a new segmented target designed to increase statistics for Radioactive Isotope Beam (RIB) experiments to study neutron-unbound systems using the invariant mass spectroscopy technique. The latter (2) will help inform the design, testing and construction of an upgraded target system, the Multilayered Active target for MoNA Experiments (MAME), that will use a gas electron multiplier (GEM) based detector to track the outgoing reaction and decay fragments. A GEANT4 simulation will be developed as part of the design process and for use in the data analysis of future experiments that will use MAME. The resulting device will provide a new tool for measuring neutron-unbound systems thus contributing to the ongoing investigation of the rich structure of atomic nuclei.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Modern efforts to study the atomic nucleus have reached an exciting juncture with the construction of the Facility for Rare Isotope Beams (FRIB). At the heart of this facility is a linear accelerator that will boost long-lived nuclei to high speeds after which they will be directed onto a target where nuclear collisions inside the target atoms will fragment the beam nuclei into lighter, short-lived, exotic nuclei. These reaction products constitute a “radioactive ion beam,” and they are still moving fast enough to be directed via magnets to any of several different experimental setups in less than a millionth of a second.

Ground-breaking experiments underway at FRIB will address important scientific questions, for example, how were the elements we observe in the universe produced through nuclear reactions in energetic astrophysical phenomena? How can nuclei be used as laboratories for exploring fundamental aspects of reality? What new technologies can nuclear science produce for the betterment of society? How can we explain the properties and phenomena exhibited by the most neutron- and proton-rich isotopes?

The Modular Neutron Array (MoNA) and the Large multi-Institutional Scintillator Array (LISA) will be incorporated into one of the aforementioned experimental stations. These arrays together consist of 288 bar-shaped plastic scintillator detectors, each measuring 200 centimeters long, 10 centimeters wide, and 10 centimeters high. These detectors are used in experiments to measure a special type of neutron-rich nucleus: neutron-unbound systems. These systems are produced in nuclear reactions between high-speed exotic nuclei produced from the accelerator and nuclei in a second target positioned a few meters from the MoNA-LISA setup. They decay as soon as they’re produced by emitting one or more neutrons, and MoNA-LISA is designed to detect these neutrons. Careful measurements of the neutrons and residual nucleus help scientists reconstruct information about the original, quickly decaying neutron-unbound system. Measuring the properties of various neutron-unbound systems is important for understanding how nuclear properties change and evolve from stable to exotic nuclear systems. This understanding is crucial to building a coherent picture of the dynamic system that is the atomic nucleus.

A major outcome from this project was a publication (PRC 109, 054325, 2024) comparing measurements of 24O and two neutrons from decays of heavier, neutron-unbound oxygen isotopes produced from beams of 27F, by removing one proton, and 29Ne, by removing two protons. The measurements from the 29Ne beam exhibited a conspicuous absense of any signature of the 26O ground state suggesting that decays of 27O states do not proceed through the 26O ground state. This, together with a recent study of 28O (Kondo et al. Nature 620, 965 2023), enabled us to draw conclusions about the level structures of 29Ne and 27O, namely that there is a degree of dissimilarity that is not currently reproduced by nuclear theory models.

A second key outcome was the development of a simulation to explore a potential upgrade to a key piece of equipment used in MoNA-LISA experiments, the segmented target. Experiments to study neutron-unbound systems are limited by the rate at which these systems can be produced in reactions between nuclei in the ion beam and nuclei in a target onto which the beam is directed. This rate depends on the intensity of the ion beam and the thickness of the target material. The beam intensity is limited by the accelerator system, and the target thickness impacts the resolution of the measurement with thicker targets resulting in worse resolution due to a larger uncertainty in the reaction location. The segmented target interleaves detectors between three target segments to circumvent this resolution degradation. The detectors enable identification of the target segment for each reaction resulting in an effectively thicker target to enhance the production rate of neutron-unbound systems while the measurement resolution is determined by the thicknesses of the target segments. The upgrade aims to replace the current detectors by enclosing the target segments in a gas-filled volume that would function as a detection system and enable a larger number of target segments to be included. However, simulations showed that measurements from the gas-filled detector would not be sufficient to identify the target segment for every reaction due to the low density of the fill gas. Further design work is needed to refine the upgrade concept.

A third major outcome is the foundation of a nuclear science research group at Virginia State University (VSU). This project provided hands-on research opportunities for five undergraduate students from VSU, one undergraduate from the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, and two graduate students from Michigan State University. In addition to the aforementioned publication, material from this work was the subject of nine student presentations at regional and national conferences and one presentation at an international nuclear structure conference. The VSU group continues to provide hands-on opportunities to undergraduate students to engage in modern nuclear science research.
